Riskvatten Introduction/background
Riskvatten Carl Tamario 2024-11-08 Introduction/background A working documents for the project Waters at Risk.
wp1-fish-species-and-vulnerable-populations.html

Chapter 1 WP1: Fish species and vulnerable populations 1.1 Background 1.2 Fish occurrences from NORS and SERS 1.3 Redlisted species 1.4 Freshwater pearl mussel 1.5 Connecting point data to river lines

Chapter 1 WP1: Fish species and vulnerable populations 1.1 Background In the fish WP, we will identify relevant and target species within each watercourse. This will be done by the combination of information from the electro fishing database (SERS), the test fishing database (NORS), as well as the Species observation system database (Artportalen), all available at SLU. In addition, the County Boards will be consulted about the fish fauna in their respective counties. When a comprehensive understanding about the fish fauna in the different watercourses has been produced, additional information about vulnerability of different species/populations will be added as an additional datasheet. The vulnerability assessment will largely be based on the Swedish Red list and County Board information about vulnerable populations including occurrence of freshwater pearl pussel. In addition, information about protected and valuable areas (Natura 2000, Nyckelbiotoper) will contribute to the overall assessment of vulnerability. 1.2 Fish occurrences from NORS and SERS Fish species occurrence in rivers and lakes was acquired from the API for databases SERS (electrofishing registry) and NORS (lake fishing registry) available at SLU (https://dvfisk.slu.se/home). 1.2.1 NORS The data files contains for each sampled lake/river summaries of which fish species are caught, the first and last sampling year, how many times it has been sampled, CPUE, the most common caught species, and more. The database contains 4176 sampled lakes. A map of all sampled lakes (and the species which are caught) can be found below. Map 1 A map of all the lake fishing sites in Sweden. There are 4183 sampled locations. The size of the point is proportional to the number of species caught. Click on the point to get the species list (in Swedish) and the name of the water body. 1.2.2 SERS Map 2 A map of all the electrofishing sites in Sweden. There are 23326 sampled locations. The size of the point is proportional to the number of species caught. Click on the point to get the species list (in Swedish) and the name of the water body. 1.2.3 Both databases combined It is possible to do sub-selections of this data if we need to extract the distribution of particular species, both for problem species (e.g., invasive) or redlisted species. Map 3. Map with both SERS (orange) and NORS (blue) combined. The size of the point is proportional to the number of species caught. Click on the point to get the database origin, the species list (in Swedish), and the name of the water body. 1.3 Redlisted species A map of the occurrences of the redlisted species with data from both SERS and NORS: aspen (asp) alpine bullhead (bergsimpa) burbot (lake) European eel (ål) sea lamprey (havsnejonöga) Wels catfish (mal) vimba bream (vimma) 1.4 Freshwater pearl mussel The endangered freshwater pearl mussel is often regarded as an indicator, keystone and umbrella species. It is present in nutrient-poor, cold, and clear rivers. It has been subject to pearl fishing but it is not so common anymore. It has a parasitic stage that involves the brown trout and/or Atlantic salmon as host species to complete its life cycle. There are about 650 populations in Sweden depending on what one assess to be an “individual population”. About half of the populations in Sweden lack recruitment, that is, during inventory of the populations, no mussels smaller than 50 mm were found. It is generally said that mussels reach around 50 mm when they are 20 years old. If there are no small (young) mussels present in the population, something is disturbing the recruitment process, either in the host species or the mussels, or both. The exact locations of populations is sensitive data because the freshwater pearl mussel have been subject to pearl fishing. To protect the populations we will only present the river section where they occur instead of the exact locations. 1.5 Connecting point data to river lines (I have been talking about this earlier, points are just points and has to be translated to the “river dimension”. However, the interactive map function (called leaflet) used above is very slow when handling the large river network. Therefore we have to go with the approach of static maps.) wp2-chemical-pollution.html
Chapter 2 WP2: Chemical pollution 2.1 Background 2.2 Data

Chapter 2 WP2: Chemical pollution 2.1 Background Chemical pollution represents a leading threat to human health, wildlife, and ecosystems around the world (Landrigan et al. 2018). In fact, increases in the diversity and volume of novel synthetic chemicals released into the environment now far outpace other key drivers of global change (e.g. rising atmospheric CO2, habitat loss; Bernhardt et al. 2017). This trend is the result of rapidly increasing chemical use, with the global chemicals industry—currently valued at >US$5 trillion—projected to double in size between 2017 and 2030 (UNEP 2019). The spread of novel environmental contaminants is concerning given that many ecosystems are already inundated with myriad organic and inorganic chemicals released by human activities, including metals, pesticides, pharmaceuticals, and per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). Moreover, chemical pollution continues to accelerate large-scale wildlife losses, including dramatic declines in the abundance and biodiversity of insects (Sánchez‐Bayo and Wyckhuys 2019), avifauna (Rosenberg et al. 2019), and aquatic species (Tickner et al. 2020). A much less studied, but very important, aspect of chemical pollution is the increased vulnerability to pathogens and parasites that exposed wildlife, like fish, experience. This reduction in immunocompetence, combined with the reduced energy available to invest in life sustaining activities, can substancially increase both frequency and severity of a pathogen in a population. Hence, it is important to include both pathogen/parasite presence and pollution load in a waterway when assessing future risk of increased connectivity. Here we will map pollution load in waterways by combining information of wastewater input in running waters (in relations to its flow) with avaliable monitoring data for key chemicals. To our knowledge this is the first time pollution load and pathogen distribution have been investigated in tandem to identify Water at Risk. 2.2 Data No data available yet
wp3-fish-health-relevant-diseases-and-syndromes.html
Chapter 3 WP3: Fish health (relevant diseases and syndromes) 3.1 Background 3.2 Reported finds to SVA 3.3 Reported outbreaks in fish farms 3.4 Kräftpest? 3.5 Gyrodactylus salaris?

Chapter 3 WP3: Fish health (relevant diseases and syndromes) 3.1 Background In the health WP, species associated with relevant diseases, bacteria and viruses will be identified together with routes of transmission. This work entails review of literature from ongoing monitoring on fish health (on wild as well as reared fish, SVA, SLU, GU) as well as an overview of current research. When a comprehensive understanding about the fish health in the different watercourses has been produced, additional information about vulnerability of different species/populations will be added as an additional datasheet. 3.2 Reported finds to SVA (Inrapporterade fynd till SVA) Mail från Charlotte Axén (2024-05-08): Kartan kan filtreras på år och fiskgrupp (ex laxfiskar). Under kartan finns en tabell över fyndplatser. Vad som rapporterats (ex svamp) framgår inte, men ni kan räkna med att i princip allt som rapporteras från september till jan-feb är svamp, med undantag för fjällsjöarna vintertid där det kommer en del rapporter om parasitangrepp på pimplad fisk. Sen kan man inte lita på att de rapporter vi får in ger en helhetsbild. Det finns säkert ett antal fler vattendrag som är drabbade men folk vet inte var de ska rapportera eller bryr sig inte om att rapportera, och en rapport speglar inte hur kraftigt angreppet är. Det vill säga: Mellan september och februari: Svamp Övrigt tid: Okänt? wp4-hydropower-activities.html
Chapter 4 WP4: Hydropower activities 4.1 Background 4.2 The national plan 4.3 Data layers available in Sweden

Chapter 4 WP4: Hydropower activities 4.1 Background Information about hydropower activities will be retrieved from the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (HaV) and the National plan for negotiation of Swedish hydropower (NAP). The Water Information System (VISS) and data from the Water authorities (Vattenmyndigheten) will also provide valuable information about lack of connectivity and suggested restoration efforts as well as the environmental quality standards (Miljökvalitetsnorm, MKN) for each watercourse. The output layer will show hydropower facilities in relation to suggested restoration measures and environmental quality standards and if the watercourse has been classified as heavily modified water (Kraftigt Modifierat Vatten, KMV). 4.2 The national plan As of november 2024, the current affairs of the National plan is as follows: 4.3 Data layers available in Sweden Unfortunately, no information can be retrieved from the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (HaV) due to classified information. Anders Skarstedt, which is our contact person at HaV for this project, is not able to give us information on what objects are included in the National plan. Other databases with barrier data include: (i) the Barrier database (Vandringshinderdatabasen; Länsstyrelserna), (ii) SMHI dam registry (Dammregistret; Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute), and (iii) Measures in water (Åtgärder i Vatten; Länsstyrelserna). All three databases include information not available in the other three, and are thus necessary compliments to each other. 4.3.1 How to proceed As we lack information about what hydropower plants are included in the National plan, we retrieved and combined barrier data from three databases on barriers in Sweden. 4.3.2 The consolidated barrier layer
wp5-invasive-species.html
Chapter 5 WP5: Invasive species 5.1 Background 5.2 Pink salmon 5.3 Signal crayfish 5.4 Lake trout 5.5 Brook trout

Chapter 5 WP5: Invasive species 5.1 Background In the Invasive species WP, we will identify distribution of invasive animal species within each watercourse. This will be done by the combination of information from the electro fishing database (SERS), the test fishing database (NORS), as well as the Species observation system database (Artportalen), all available at SLU. In addition, the County Boards will be consulted about the fish fauna in their respective counties. These distributions will be included in the Invasive species GIS-sheet and will be used to improve risk assessment. 5.2 Pink salmon Background: Pink salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha) was introduced to the Kola Peninsula in Russia in 1956. In 2021, Norway saw an unprecedented occurrence of pink salmon in coastal and freshwater catches. Occurrences in Sweden are still relatively sparse, but also Sweden saw the highest occurrence thus far in 2021 (Staveley & Ahlbeck 2022). There are no reported successful reproductions in Sweden, unlike in Norway and the United Kingdom. Geographical extent of risk: The coastal water zone on the west coast is the most vulnerable, but also around the southern coast (Staveley & Ahlbeck, 2022). Potential consequences: Pink salmon occur in the river systems at the same time as Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) and brown trout (S. trutta) and could therefore potentially interfere with their spawning. However, it is not established whether they actually pose a threat to the Atlantic salmon (JONSSON) Recommended actions: Data availability on Swedish occurrence: Yes, up to 2021 (Staveley & Ahlbeck 2022). There are also 16 datapoints without exact geolocation in 5.3 Signal crayfish Background: The signal crayfish (Pacifastacus leniusculus) was introduced to Swedish waters in 1969 as a response to the mortality of the European crayfish (Astacus astacus) due to the crayfish plague (Aphanomyces astaci). Its origin is northwestern USA and southwestern Canada, and is on the EU list of invasive species. That means that it is forbidden to stock and translocate in nature. It is morphologically very similar to the native European crayfish. Geographical extent of risk: In southern and middle Sweden, up to Dalarna (Siljan), Hälsingland and in a few locations along the Norrland coast. 4000 locations, but with illegal stocking it may be present in more locations. Signal crayfish is now widespread all over Europe. Potential consequences: Signal crayfish is more aggressive and displaces European crayfish to the shoreline (REF). Coexistence happens but is rare because the signal crayfish often carries the crayfish plague that spreads to its vulnerable European relatives and therefore kills them. The signal crayfish has therefore replaced the European crayfish in many areas. Recommended actions: The natural movement/spread of signal crayfish is limited due to a low migration propensity. Individual crayfish are relatively stationary and seldom move over 500 meters within a year. Studies say that their low movement is also due to barriers. This implies that dam removal may allow signal crayfish to spread. The larger problem regarding is illegal stocking and translocations. The management program for signal crayfish in Sweden can be found here. Data availability on Swedish occurrence: Yes. (All signal crayfish occurrences fetched 2024-10-22; N = 18755) https://www.slu.se/institutioner/akvatiska-resurser/databaser/nationella-kraftdatabasen/ 5.4 Lake trout Background: Lake trout origins from North America and has been introduced into 110 lakes and reservoirs between 1960 and 1985. Reports say that successful reproduction has happened in a few lakes, e.g., [Storsjön and Kallsjön in Jämtland] (https://artfakta.se/taxa/206233/information). Geographical extent of risk: Lake trout thrives in deep and cold waters of the north. Not many follow-up studies has been done. Johan Östergren is doing a project (FÅK återbesökt) that will map where lake trout was introduced, where it has been reproducing, and what potential consequences there are for biodiversity. Potential consequences: (What does Östergren study conclude?) Recommended actions: (What does Östergrens study conclude?) Data availability on Swedish occurrence: There is a data-file available from Johan Östergren. This file will be used in other research papers by Östergren and is sensitive data. 5.5 Brook trout Background: Geographical extent of risk: Potential consequences: Recommended actions: Data availability on Swedish occurrence: Yes, through SERS and NORS.
